title: Dragon's Den star Peter Jones fights to secure rescue deal for Jessops
text:
Dragons’ Den star Peter Jones is fighting to secure the future of camera chain Jessops as he prepares to call in administrators.

He reportedly plans to seek a rescue deal for the firm’s property arm, JR Prop Limited, putting the future of 46 stores in jeopardy.

The proposed company voluntary arrangement (CVA) with creditors could see it shut unprofitable sites and slash rents.

On the brink: Camera chain Jessops was founded in 1935 in Leicester and employs around 500 staff in the stores

Jessops was founded in 1935 in Leicester and employs around 500 staff in the stores.

Jones bought it in 2013 after it collapsed under £81million in debt, leading to the closure of all its 187 stores and the loss of almost 1,500 jobs.

Rescue bid: Dragon's Den star Peter Jones

The BBC star relaunched Jessops two months later as part of a £4million investment, hiring former staff who had lost their jobs.

Since then, the firm has seen profits fall from more than £700,000 in 2016 to less than £10,000 last year.

A CVA is an insolvency process that allows a business to reach an agreement with its creditors to pay off all or part of its debts and is often used as an chance to renegotiate rents.
